subsections.description: Continuation of divisibility proof by induction

content.step: (2) If P_k is true, then 2^{k+2} + 3^{3k} = 5A where A is an integer.
derivation: = 5(2A + 5 × 3^{3k}) where 2A + 5 × 3^{3k} is an integer as A is an integer and k ≥ 0 is an integer.
content.conclusion: Thus 2^{(k+1)+2} + 3^{3(k+1)} is divisible by 5 whenever 2^{k+2} + 3^{3k} is divisible by 5. Since P_0 is true, and P_{k+1} is true whenever P_k is true, P_n is true for all n ∈ Z, n ≥ 0. {principle of mathematical induction}

subsections.title: Factor proof by induction
subsections.problem: Prove that x^n - y^n has a factor (x - y) for all n ∈ Z^+.

solution.proposition: P_n is: x^n - y^n has a factor (x - y) for all n ∈ Z^+.
solution.base_case: (1) If n = 1, x^1 - y^1 = x - y which has (x - y) as a factor. ∴ P_1 is true.

inductive_step.assumption: (2) If P_k is true, then x^k - y^k has a factor (x - y).
derivation: = x(x^k - y^k) + x × y^k - y × y^k
using P_k this term has factor (x - y), this term has factor (x - y)
inductive_step.conclusion: Thus x^{k+1} - y^{k+1} has a factor (x - y) whenever x^k - y^k has a factor (x - y). Since P_1 is true, and P_{k+1} is true whenever P_k is true, P_n is true for all n ∈ Z^+. {principle of mathematical induction}

subsections.problem: A sequence is defined by u_1 = 1 and u_{n+1} = 2u_n + 1 for all n ∈ Z^+. Prove that u_n = 2^n - 1 for all n ∈ Z^+.

solution.proposition: P_n is: if u_1 = 1 and u_{n+1} = 2u_n + 1 for all n ∈ Z^+, then u_n = 2^n - 1.

inductive_step.assumption: (2) If P_k is true, then u_k = 2^k - 1

subsections.content: Sometimes, in order to prove the next inductive step, we require the previous two cases. Another form of the principle of mathematical induction is therefore: Suppose P_n is a proposition defined for all n ∈ Z^+. If P_1 and P_2 are true, and also P_{k+1} is true whenever P_k and P_{k-1} are true, then P_n is true for all n ∈ Z^+. Use this form, P_n is true for all n ≥ n_0.

subsections.title: Trigonometric sum proof
subsections.problem: Use the principle of mathematical induction to prove that: 2cos(x) + 2cos(4x) + 2cos(6x) + ... + 2cos(2nx) = (sin(2n+1)x - 1)/sin(x) for all n ∈ Z^+.

solution.proposition: P_n is: 2cos(2x) + 2cos(4x) + 2cos(6x) + ... + 2cos(2nx) = (sin(2n+1)x)/sin(x) - 1 for all n ∈ Z^+.
solution.base_case: (1) If n = 1, LHS = 2cos(2x) and RHS = (sin(3x) - sin(x))/sin(x) = (sin(3x)/sin(x)) - 1 = (sin(2x)cos(x) + cos(2x)sin(x))/sin(x) - 1 = (sin(x)·2cos(x)·cos(x) + cos(2x)sin(x))/sin(x) - 1 = 2cos^2(x) + cos(2x) - 1 = (2cos^2(x) - 1) + cos(2x) = cos(2x) + cos(2x) = 2cos(2x). ∴ P_1 is true.

inductive_step.conclusion: Since P_1 is true, and P_{k+1} is true whenever P_k is true, P_n is true for all n ∈ Z^+. {principle of mathematical induction}

subsections.title: Inequality proof by induction
subsections.problem: Prove that 2^{-n} < 1/n for all n ∈ Z^+.

solution.proposition: P_n is: 2^{-n} < 1/n for all n ∈ Z^+.
solution.base_case: (1) If n = 1, LHS = 2^{-1} = 1/2 and RHS = 1/1 = 1. ∴ P_1 is true.

inductive_step.assumption: (2) If P_k is true, then 2^{-k} < 1/k for some k ≥ 1.
inductive_step.conclusion: Since P_1 is true, and P_{k+1} is true whenever P_k is true, P_n is true for all n ∈ Z^+. {principle of mathematical induction}

subsections.title: Polygon diagonals proof
subsections.problem: Prove that a convex n-sided polygon has (1/2)n(n-3) diagonals for all n ≥ 3.

solution.proposition: P_n is: A convex n-sided polygon has (1/2)n(n-3) diagonals for all n ≥ 3.
solution.base_case: (1) If n = 3 we have a triangle with 0 diagonals, and (1/2) × 3 × 0 = 0. ∴ P_3 is true.

inductive_step.assumption: (2) If P_k is true, a convex k-sided polygon has (1/2)k(k-3) diagonals. We label the vertices 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, ...., k-1, k and k+1 as an additional vertex.
derivation: The number of diagonals when n = k+1 is the number of diagonals when n = k, + k - 2 + 1
- the line from vertex 1 to vertex k was previously a side and is now a diagonal
- the number of diagonals from vertex k+1 to the vertices 2, 3, 4, 5, ...., k-1
∴ the number of diagonals when n = k+1 is:
inductive_step.conclusion: Since P_3 is true, and P_{k+1} is true whenever P_k is true, P_n is true for all n ≥ 3. {principle of mathematical induction}
